Moreover, the octapeptide does not contain the GPP* sequence involved in platelet aggregation mediated by GP VI (31.Knight C.G. Morton L.F. Onley D.J. Peachey A.R. Ichinohe T. Okuma M. Farndale R.W. Barnes M.J. Cardiovasc. Res. 1999; 41: 450-457Crossref PubMed Scopus (188) Google Scholar). In the present study, we investigated the role of the octapeptide in the first steps of platelet activation, i.e. platelet collagen contact and spreading under static conditions, and platelet collagen interactions under flow conditions. In our assay, platelet contact with collagen is cation-independent (26.Fauvel-Lafève F. Meric A. Arbeille B. Tabaka V. Legrand Y.J. Thromb. Res. 1993; 71: 193-204Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (10) Google Scholar), does not induce platelet activation, and is not mediated by GP Ia/IIa, GP IIb/IIIa, or GP IV (7.Monnet, E., Sizaret, P. Y., Arbeille, B., and Fauvel-Lafève, F. (2000) Thromb. Res., in pressGoogle Scholar). On the other hand, platelet contact with type III collagen was specifically inhibited by the octapeptide, indicating that this peptide binds to a primary platelet receptor for this particular collagen. The absence of octapeptide initial binding peptide to GP Ia/IIa confirms that the latter is not involved in the initial contact between platelets and collagen (7.Monnet, E., Sizaret, P. Y., Arbeille, B., and Fauvel-Lafève, F. (2000) Thromb. Res., in pressGoogle Scholar). The octapeptide also inhibits platelet spreading on immobilized type III collagen. Moreover, octapeptide immobilized on plastic induced platelet adhesion and serotonin release equivalent to those of type III collagen. The proximity of octapeptides in the wells favored platelet adhesion and help to cluster high numbers of platelet receptors on one side of the platelets. The clustering of these receptors could induce platelet activation, as assessed by serotonin release and the phosphorylation of signal proteins under these conditions (data not shown). Moreover, platelet adhesion to the octapeptide was not inhibited by antibodies directed against other collagen receptors including GP Ia, GP IV, p65, and p47 (Fig. 7 B). This observation further supports that GP Ia/IIa is not involved in the first steps of platelet type III collagen interaction (7.Monnet, E., Sizaret, P. Y., Arbeille, B., and Fauvel-Lafève, F. (2000) Thromb. Res., in pressGoogle Scholar). Platelet adhesion to HUVEC matrix under static conditions was inhibited by 0.5 mm octapeptide, but the inhibition was not complete, indicating that platelets may also react with other molecules expressed in the matrix. Under flow conditions, the octapeptide inhibited platelet adhesion and aggregation induced by type III collagen at two shear rates (300 and 1500 s−1) but had no effect on platelet type I collagen interaction, supporting the high specificity of its action. At low shear rate (300 s−1), on the octapeptide fewer and smaller aggregates were formed, and this observation was further accentuated at the high shear rate (1500 s−1). Thus, at the low shear rate, as under static conditions, platelet adhesion was followed by platelet activation. The surface covered at low shear rate was higher (7%) than that observed (1%) by Verkleij et al. (30.Verkleij M.W. Ijsseldijk M.J.W. Heijnen-Snyder G.J. Hulzinga E.G. Morton L.F. Knight C.G. Sixma J.J. de Groot P.G. Barnes M.J. Thromb. Haemost. 1999; 82: 1137-1144Crossref PubMed Scopus (17) Google Scholar) for the CB4(III)-4 peptide, which contains the octapeptide, probably because this sequence is less accessible in a larger peptide. At the high shear rate (1500 s−1), the absence of platelet aggregate formation on the octapeptide could be due to the inability of plasma von Willebrand factor (vWF) to bind to the octapeptide like to CB4(III)-4 (30.Verkleij M.W. Ijsseldijk M.J.W. Heijnen-Snyder G.J. Hulzinga E.G. Morton L.F. Knight C.G. Sixma J.J. de Groot P.G. Barnes M.J. Thromb. Haemost. 1999; 82: 1137-1144Crossref PubMed Scopus (17) Google Scholar), because vWF is necessary for the maintenance of platelet aggregates at a high shear rate. The binding of plasma vWF to the entire type III collagen could explain the presence of sparse small aggregates when platelets where incubated with 0.5 mmoctapeptide before perfusion (Fig. 4 B, 3). The specificity of the binding was assessed with the competition studies: the binding was displaced by a 60-fold excess of unlabeled octapeptide. Ligand blotting, after SDS-PAGE of total platelet proteins, showed that the octapeptide bound to a doublet of proteins with molecular masses of 68 (major) and 72 kDa. This dual binding indicates that the octapeptide also recognizes its platelet receptor under denatured conditions. The protein doublet does not correspond to any already known collagen receptor. The doublet is not stained by the Schiff reagent, indicating that it is not glycosylated. The major band was composed by four isoforms with different phosphorylation states, as observed after immunoblotting with an anti-phosphotyrosine kinase that labeled two spots (data not shown). In conclusion, platelet adhesion to type III collagen occurs via a specific non integrin receptor, TIIICBP. This receptor is involved in the contact between platelet and collagen, and our studies under flow conditions demonstrated that platelet TIIICBP reacted directly with the octapeptide or type III collagen. Further investigations are needed to elucidate octapeptide-induced activation pathway and to determine whether eventual interactions with other collagen receptors, for example GP VI, could reinforce platelet aggregation. Nonetheless, results presented herein allow us to complete the model proposed by Verkleij et al. (32.Verkleij M.W. Morton L.F. Knight C.G. de Groot P.G. Barnes M.J. Sixma J.J Blood. 1998; 91: 3808-3816Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). Unlike the collagen-related peptides used in their study (32.Verkleij M.W. Morton L.F. Knight C.G. de Groot P.G. Barnes M.J. Sixma J.J Blood. 1998; 91: 3808-3816Crossref PubMed Google Scholar), the octapeptide favored platelet adhesion under flow conditions, as shown in Fig.8. During the first step, arrest of platelets on type III collagen, platelet TIIICBP would bind to the octapeptide in CB4(III)-4 (positions 487–495). Very close to this first interaction, platelet GP Ib would react with vWF bound in CB4(III)-7 (residues 541–558) (32.Verkleij M.W. Morton L.F. Knight C.G. de Groot P.G. Barnes M.J. Sixma J.J Blood. 1998; 91: 3808-3816Crossref PubMed Google Scholar), and the adhesion would then be stabilized by the binding of GP Ia/IIa to CB4(III)6/7 (residues 522–528) (30.Verkleij M.W. Ijsseldijk M.J.W. Heijnen-Snyder G.J. Hulzinga E.G. Morton L.F. Knight C.G. Sixma J.J. de Groot P.G. Barnes M.J. Thromb. Haemost. 1999; 82: 1137-1144Crossref PubMed Scopus (17) Google Scholar). Finally, the binding of GP VI to the collagen triple helix, and the eventual participation of other receptors (p47?) (16.Chiang T.M. Seyer J.M. Kang A.H. Thromb. Res. 1993; 71: 443-456Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (23) Google Scholar) would reinforce platelet activation, leading to the formation of large thrombi. Taken together, the results of these studies show that type III collagen has several platelet-binding sites condensed in a small region within the CB4 peptide, a system that could provide a solid foundation for platelet adhesion and aggregation, thereby assuring adequate thrombus formation. We thank Janet Jacobson for the English version of the article.

Sodium salicylate inhibits activation of the transcription factor NF-κB by blocking the phosphorylation and degradation of the NF-κB inhibitor IκBα. We previously demonstrated that salicylate inhibits IκBα degradation induced by tumor necrosis factor (TNF) but not by interleukin-1 (IL-1) and implicated p38 mitogen-activated protein kinase activation by salicylate in the inhibition of TNF-induced IκBα phosphorylation. Both TNF and IL-1 rapidly activate the IκB kinase (IKK) complex, containing the catalytic subunits IKKα and IKKβ, which directly phosphorylates IκB proteins. Others have recently suggested that salicylate inhibits NF-κB activation by directly binding to IKKβ. To clarify the mechanism whereby salicylate inhibits IKK activity, we examined its effects upon cytokine-induced IKK activity in intact cells and in vitro. Treatment of intact cells with salicylate inhibited TNF-induced but not IL-1-induced IKK activity, and this inhibition was prevented by the p38 inhibitor SB203580. In contrast, inhibition of IKK activity by salicylate in vitro was neither selective for TNF nor affected by SB203580. In vitro, salicylate treatment comparably inhibited the kinase activity of overexpressed IKKα and IKKβ and also decreased p38 kinase activity. Therefore, direct inhibition of IKK activity in vitro does not reflect the inhibitory mechanism of salicylate in intact cells, which involves interference with TNF signaling. We previously demonstrated that salicylate inhibits IκBα degradation induced by tumor necrosis factor (TNF) but not by interleukin-1 (IL-1) and implicated p38 mitogen-activated protein kinase activation by salicylate in the inhibition of TNF-induced IκBα phosphorylation. In contrast, inhibition of IKK activity by salicylate in vitro was neither selective for TNF nor affected by SB203580. Therefore, direct inhibition of IKK activity in vitro does not reflect the inhibitory mechanism of salicylate in intact cells, which involves interference with TNF signaling. nuclear factor κB tumor necrosis factor interleukin-1 inhibitor of NF-κB IκB kinase NF-κB-inducing kinase mitogen-activated protein kinase extracellular signal-regulated kinase MAP/ERK kinase kinase 1 sodium salicylate Dulbecco's modified Eagle's medium fetal bovine serum minimal essential medium myelin basic protein glutathione S-transferase polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis The transcription factor NF-κB1 is an important regulator of genes involved in immune and inflammatory responses. The NF-κB pathway is activated by a variety of stimuli, including the cytokines tumor necrosis factor (TNF) and interleukin-1 (IL-1) and bacterial lipopolysaccharide. In most mammalian cells, the NF-κB dimer is sequestered in the cytoplasm by an inhibitory IκB isoform such as IκBα, IκBβ, or IκBε (1.Baldwin Jr., A.S. Annu. Rev. Immunol. 1996; 14: 649-683Crossref PubMed Scopus (5579) Google Scholar). Stimulus-induced phosphorylation of IκB proteins on two conserved N-terminal serine residues leads to IκB degradation via the ubiquitin-proteasome pathway allowing for the release of NF-κB and its nuclear translocation. TNF-induced NF-κB activation is initiated by oligomerization of the type 1 or type 2 TNF receptors. This leads to the recruitment of cytoplasmic signaling proteins, such as TNF receptor-associated death domain, TNF receptor-associated factor 2 and receptor interacting protein, and activation of kinases including MAP/ERK kinase kinase 1 (MEKK1) and the NF-κB-inducing kinase (NIK) (2.Malinin N.L. Boldin M.P. Kovalenko A.V. Wallach D. Nature. 1997; 385: 540-544Crossref PubMed Scopus (1165) Google Scholar, 3.Lee F.S. Hagler J. Chen Z.J. Maniatis T. Cell. 1997; 88: 213-222Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (660) Google Scholar, 4.Wallach D. Varfolomeev E.E. Malinin N.L. Goltsev Y.V. Kovalenko A.V. Boldin M.P. Annu. Rev. Immunol. 1999; 17: 331-367Crossref PubMed Scopus (1125) Google Scholar, 5.Darnay B.G. Aggarwal B.B. J. Leukocyte Biol. 1997; 61: 559-566Crossref PubMed Scopus (168) Google Scholar). Both NIK and MEKK1 can activate a multiprotein IκB kinase (IKK) complex of 700–900 kDa that is responsible for directly phosphorylating IκB isoforms (3.Lee F.S. Hagler J. Chen Z.J. Maniatis T. Cell. 1997; 88: 213-222Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (660) Google Scholar, 6.Regnier C.H. Song H.Y. Gao X. Goeddel D.V. Cao Z. Rothe M. Cell. 1997; 90: 373-383Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (1072) Google Scholar, 7.DiDonato J.A. Hayakawa M. Rothwarf D.M. Zandi E. Karin M. Science. 1997; 278: 860-866Crossref PubMed Scopus (1853) Google Scholar). The IKK complex consists of two catalytic components, IKKα and IKKβ, as well as a regulatory IKKγ subunit, which may facilitate interaction with upstream signaling factors (9.Zandi E. Rothwarf D.M. Delhase M. Hayakawa M. Karin M. Cell. 1997; 91: 243-252Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (1589) Google Scholar, 10.Yamaoka S. Courtois G. Bessia C. Whiteside S.T. Weil R. Agou F. Nature. 1998; 395: 297-300Crossref PubMed Scopus (853) Google Scholar). Other proteins, such as IKK complex associated protein (12.Cohen L. Henzel W.J. Baeuerle P.A. Nature. 1998; 395: 292-296Crossref PubMed Scopus (270) Google Scholar), have been shown to interact with the IKK complex, and their precise roles in the activation of the IKK complex remain to be defined. Salicylate and its acetylated derivative, aspirin (acetylsalicylic acid), represent the oldest known nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs. A well characterized mechanism of action for aspirin involves the acetylation of cyclooxygenase isoforms, leading to irreversible inhibition of prostaglandin synthesis (13.Vane J.R. Nat. New Biol. 1971; 231: 232-235Crossref PubMed Scopus (7347) Google Scholar). In the intact organism, aspirin is rapidly deacetylated to salicylate, which is a relatively weak inhibitor of cyclooxygenases (14.Weissmann G. Sci. Am. 1991; 264: 84-90Crossref PubMed Scopus (232) Google Scholar). Nonetheless, both aspirin and salicylate are potent anti-inflammatory agents, used in the treatment of chronic inflammatory disorders such as rheumatoid arthritis (14.Weissmann G. Sci. Am. 1991; 264: 84-90Crossref PubMed Scopus (232) Google Scholar,15.Abramson S.B. Weissmann G. Arthritis Rheum. 1989; 32: 1-9Crossref PubMed Scopus (418) Google Scholar). Sodium salicylate (NaSal) and aspirin can inhibit the activation of NF-κB by preventing the phosphorylation and degradation of IκBα (16.Kopp E. Ghosh S. Science. 1994; 265: 956-959Crossref PubMed Scopus (1617) Google Scholar, 17.Pierce J.W. Read M.A. Ding H. Luscinskas F.W. Collins T. J. Immunol. 1996; 156: 3961-3969PubMed Google Scholar), and inhibition of NF-κB may explain some of the clinically documented anti-inflammatory effects seen with high concentrations of salicylates (14.Weissmann G. Sci. Am. 1991; 264: 84-90Crossref PubMed Scopus (232) Google Scholar, 15.Abramson S.B. Weissmann G. Arthritis Rheum. 1989; 32: 1-9Crossref PubMed Scopus (418) Google Scholar). We have demonstrated that NaSal rapidly and persistently activates p38 MAP kinase and that NaSal-induced p38 activation is important for its ability to inhibit TNF-induced IκBα phosphorylation and degradation (18.Schwenger P. Bellosta P. Vietor I. Basilico C. Skolnik E.Y. Vilcek J. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1997; 94: 2869-2873Crossref PubMed Scopus (256) Google Scholar, 19.Schwenger P. Alpert D. Skolnik E.Y. Vilcek J. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1998; 18: 78-84Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). Furthermore, we have demonstrated that p38 activation may play a more general role in the inhibition of TNF-induced NF-κB activation (20.Alpert D. Schwenger P. Han J. Vilcek J. J. Biol. Chem. 1999; 274: 22176-22183Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (100) Google Scholar). A recent report has suggested that NaSal and aspirin may inhibit NF-κB by an alternative mechanism, via direct binding to the IKK complex (21.Yin M.J. Yamamoto Y. Gaynor R.B. Nature. 1998; 396: 77-80Crossref PubMed Scopus (1434) Google Scholar). In this study, we sought to clarify the mechanism by which NaSal inhibits IKK activity. We demonstrate that treatment of intact cells with NaSal selectively inhibits IKK activity induced by TNF, yet not by IL-1, and this inhibition is prevented by the p38 inhibitor SB203580. However, we find that inhibition of IKK activity in vitro is not selective and cannot be prevented by SB203580, suggesting that direct inhibition of the IKK complex is not likely to be the mechanism by which NaSal exerts its inhibitory effect upon NF-κB activationin vivo. Normal human diploid FS-4 fibroblasts were cultured in Eagle's minimal essential medium (MEM) supplemented with 5% FBS and were serum-starved for 2–3 days in MEM with 0.25% FBS before use in experiments. To immunoprecipitate the endogenous IKK complex, equal amounts of lysates were incubated for 1–2 h at 4 °C with anti-IKKα antibody followed by collection of immune complexes for 2 h at 4 °C using protein A/G PLUS-agarose beads (Santa Cruz Biotechnology). For immunoprecipitation of transfected FLAG-IKKα, FLAG-IKKβ, or FLAG-p38α, equal amounts of lysates were incubated with anti-FLAG M2 antibody followed by collection of immune complexes using protein G-agarose beads (Life Technologies, Inc.). The immunoprecipitates were subsequently washed three times with lysis buffer and once with kinase buffer without ATP. Assays for IKK activity were performed for 30 min at 30 °C in kinase buffer consisting of 20 mm Hepes (pH 7.6), 20 mm MgCl2, 20 mmβ-glycerophosphate, 10 mm NaF, 0.2 mm sodium orthovanadate, 0.2 mm dithiothreitol, 10 mmATP, 10 mCi of [γ-32P] ATP, and 5 μg of GST-IκBα (1–62) as substrate. Assays for p38 kinase activity were performed under identical conditions in kinase buffer containing 5 μg of MBP as substrate. Kinase reactions were terminated by the addition of 2× protein sample buffer, and phosphorylated GST-IκBα or MBP was visualized following SDS-polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis (PAGE) and autoradiography. To determine the effect of NaSal treatment in vitro upon IKK activity, aliquots of immunoprecipitates were incubated with various concentrations of NaSal in kinase buffer for 30 min on ice. Kinase assays were then performed as described above in the continuous presence of NaSal. Immunoblot analysis was performed as described (20.Alpert D. Schwenger P. Han J. Vilcek J. J. Biol. Membranes were then incubated overnight at 4 °C with primary antibody. A preponderance of evidence suggests that both TNF and IL-1 induce IκBα phosphorylation and degradation via activation of the IKK complex (23.Woronicz J.D. Gao X. Cao Z. Rothe M. Goeddel D.V. Science. 1997; 278: 866-869Crossref PubMed Scopus (1068) Google Scholar, 27.Delhase M. Hayakawa M. Chen Y. Karin M. Science. 1999; 284: 309-313Crossref PubMed Scopus (752) Google Scholar). To determine whether blockage of IκBα degradation correlates with inhibition of IKK activity, we treated COS-1 cells with various concentrations of NaSal prior to stimulation with TNF or IL-1. An antibody to IKKα was used to immunoprecipitate endogenous IKK complexes from whole cell lysates (21.Yin M.J. Yamamoto Y. Gaynor R.B. Nature. 1998; 396: 77-80Crossref PubMed Scopus (1434) Google Scholar), which were then assayed forin vitro kinase activity using GST-IκBα as substrate. NaSal inhibited TNF-induced IKK activity in a dose-dependent manner with an IC50 of approximately 5 mm (Fig.1 A, top panel). In contrast, NaSal did not appreciably affect IL-1-induced IKK activity. This profile of IKK inhibition is consistent with the selective inhibition of TNF-induced IκBα degradation by NaSal (19.Schwenger P. Alpert D. Skolnik E.Y. Vilcek J. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1998; 18: 78-84Crossref PubMed Google Scholar) as demonstrated by immunoblot analysis of whole cell lysates using an antibody against IκBα (Fig. 1 A, bottom panel). TNF-induced IκBα degradation was dose-dependently inhibited by NaSal treatment. Although IL-1 induced a less complete degradation of IκBα, this effect was not inhibited at the concentrations of NaSal tested. Yin et al. (21.Yin M.J. Yamamoto Y. Gaynor R.B. Nature. 1998; 396: 77-80Crossref PubMed Scopus (1434) Google Scholar) reported that NaSal and aspirin inhibit IKK activity in vitro by directly binding to IKKβ and postulated this as the mechanism whereby salicylates inhibit NF-κB activation. It seemed difficult to reconcile the notion that NaSal directly binds and inhibits the IKK complex with our finding of selective inhibition of TNF-induced but not IL-1-induced IKK activation by NaSal. We therefore examined the effect of NaSal upon IKK activityin vitro. COS-1 cells were treated with either TNF or IL-1 for 10 min followed by immunoprecipitation of the endogenous IKK complex. The immune complexes were divided into equal fractions, which were incubated with various concentrations of NaSal for 30 min, followed by an in vitro kinase assay. In contrast to the selective inhibition of TNF-induced IKK activity observed in intact cells treated with NaSal, in vitro treatment with NaSal caused a comparable dose-dependent inhibition of both TNF- and IL-1-activated IKK activity (Fig. 1 B). NaSal leads to a rapid and persistent activation of p38 MAP kinase (18.Schwenger P. Bellosta P. Vietor I. Basilico C. Skolnik E.Y. Vilcek J. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1997; 94: 2869-2873Crossref PubMed Scopus (256) Google Scholar, 19.Schwenger P. Alpert D. Skolnik E.Y. Vilcek J. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1998; 18: 78-84Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 28.Engelman J.A. Berg A.H. Lewis R.Y. Lin A. Lisanti M.P. Scherer P.E. J. Biol. Chem. 1999; 274: 35630-35638Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (99) Google Scholar). We have shown that inhibition of TNF-induced IκBα phosphorylation and degradation by NaSal is preventable by the p38 inhibitor SB203580 (19.Schwenger P. Alpert D. Skolnik E.Y. Vilcek J. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1998; 18: 78-84Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). To determine whether SB203580 can reverse the inhibition of TNF-induced IKK activity, COS-1 cells were incubated with SB203580 or Me2SO vehicle prior to the addition of NaSal. Cells were harvested following a 10-min treatment with TNF, and the IKK complex was immunoprecipitated from whole cell lysates and assayed for in vitro kinase activity with GST-IκBα as substrate. NaSal (20 mm) strongly inhibited TNF-induced IKK activity, and this inhibition was significantly reversed by SB203580 (Fig.2 A, top panel). In addition, immunoblot analysis of cell lysates with an antibody against IκBα demonstrated that TNF-induced IκBα degradation was inhibited by NaSal, and SB203580 prevented this inhibition (Fig.2 A, bottom panel). To determine whether SB203580 can reverse the inhibitory effect of NaSal on IKK activity in vitro, IKK complexes were immunoprecipitated from untreated or TNF-treated COS cells and incubated with either SB203580 or Me2SO prior to treatment with 5 or 20 mm NaSal. Immunoprecipitated IKK was then assayed for in vitro kinase activity with GST-IκBα as substrate. NaSal dose-dependently inhibited TNF-induced IKK activity in vitro. However, contrary to the reversal observed in intact cells (Fig. 2 A), SB203580 treatment failed to reverse the inhibition by NaSal in vitro (Fig.2 B). Although NaSal strongly inhibits IκBα degradation in numerous cell systems (17.Pierce J.W. Read M.A. Ding H. Luscinskas F.W. Collins T. J. Immunol. 1996; 156: 3961-3969PubMed Google Scholar), it fails to appreciably inhibit this step in human FS-4 fibroblasts (20.Alpert D. Schwenger P. Han J. Vilcek J. J. Biol. Chem. 1999; 274: 22176-22183Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (100) Google Scholar). Consistent with this observation, treatment of intact FS-4 cells with 5 or 20 mm NaSal did not markedly affect TNF-induced IKK activity (Fig.3 A, top panel). Immunoblot analysis of these lysates with an antibody against IκBα confirmed the inability of NaSal to inhibit TNF-induced IκBα degradation (bottom panel). In contrast, treatment of immunoprecipitated IKK with NaSal in vitro inhibited IKK activity, especially at a concentration of 20 mm (Fig.3 B). To determine whether the inhibitory effect of NaSalin vitro is selective for either the IKKα or IKKβ catalytic components of the IKK complex, we transfected COS-1 cells with expression vectors encoding FLAG-IKKα or FLAG-IKKβ. Because the kinase activity of overexpressed IKKβ is at least 20 times higher than that of IKKα (23.Woronicz J.D. Gao X. Cao Z. Rothe M. Goeddel D.V. Science. 1997; 278: 866-869Crossref PubMed Scopus (1068) Google Scholar), we cotransfected NIK along with IKKα to augment its in vitro kinase activity. FLAG-tagged IKKs were immunoprecipitated from whole cell extracts and used in an in vitro kinase assay with GST-IκBα as substrate in the presence of 0, 5, or 20 mm NaSal. NaSal dose-dependently inhibited IKKα activity in the presence or absence of cotransfected NIK in addition to inhibiting IKKβ activity in vitro (Fig.4, top panel). Levels of immunoprecipitated IKKα and IKKβ were equivalent in all lanes as demonstrated by immunoblot analysis (Fig. 4, bottom panel). To determine whether the in vitro inhibitory effect of NaSal is specific for IKKs or whether other kinases are also affected, we analyzed the effect of NaSal treatment upon in vitro p38 kinase activity. COS-1 cells were transfected with FLAG-tagged p38α and either left untreated or treated with arsenite for 15 min to activate p38. FLAG-tagged p38 was immunoprecipitated from whole cell extracts and used in an in vitro kinase assay with MBP as substrate in the presence of 0, 5, or 20 mm NaSal. Arsenite stimulated p38 kinase activity above baseline, and both baseline and arsenite-stimulated p38 activity were inhibited dose-dependently by NaSal treatment in vitro(Fig. 5, top panel). Expression of immunoprecipitated FLAG-p38 was equivalent in all lanes (Fig. 5, bottom panel). We also observed that in vitro treatment with 5 and 20 mm NaSal inhibited the kinase activity of endogenous p38 activated by TNF treatment (data not shown). Because treatment of cells with NaSal has been shown to activate p38 MAP kinase (18.Schwenger P. Bellosta P. Vietor I. Basilico C. Skolnik E.Y. Vilcek J. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1997; 94: 2869-2873Crossref PubMed Scopus (256) Google Scholar, 19.Schwenger P. Alpert D. Skolnik E.Y. Vilcek J. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1998; 18: 78-84Crossref PubMed Google Scholar), the inhibitory effect of NaSal upon p38 activity supports the argument that the effect of NaSal upon kinase activity in vitro does not reflect the action of NaSal in intact cells. It has been shown that NaSal and aspirin inhibit NF-κB activation by preventing the phosphorylation and subsequent degradation of IκBα (16.Kopp E. Ghosh S. Science. 1994; 265: 956-959Crossref PubMed Scopus (1617) Google Scholar, 17.Pierce J.W. Read M.A. Ding H. Luscinskas F.W. Collins T. J. Immunol. 1996; 156: 3961-3969PubMed Google Scholar). NaSal inhibits IκBα phosphorylation and degradation induced by TNF but not by IL-1 (19.Schwenger P. Alpert D. Skolnik E.Y. Vilcek J. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1998; 18: 78-84Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 26.Madge L.A. Sierra-Honigmann M.R. Pober J.S. J. Biol. Chem. 1999; 274: 13643-13649Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (64) Google Scholar). The ability of NaSal to inhibit TNF-induced IκBα phosphorylation is dependent upon NaSal-induced p38 MAP kinase activation, and p38 may play a more general role in the inhibition of TNF-induced NF-κB activation (19.Schwenger P. Alpert D. Skolnik E.Y. Vilcek J. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1998; 18: 78-84Crossref PubMed Google Scholar,20.Alpert D. Schwenger P. Han J. Vilcek J. J. Biol. Chem. 1999; 274: 22176-22183Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (100) Google Scholar). Recently, Yin et al. (21.Yin M.J. Yamamoto Y. Gaynor R.B. Nature. 1998; 396: 77-80Crossref PubMed Scopus (1434) Google Scholar) have reported that NaSal and aspirin may inhibit the IKK complex by directly binding to IKKβ, thereby interfering with ATP binding. Because both TNF and IL-1 activate the IKK complex (23.Woronicz J.D. Gao X. Cao Z. Rothe M. Goeddel D.V. Science. 1997; 278: 866-869Crossref PubMed Scopus (1068) Google Scholar, 27.Delhase M. Hayakawa M. Chen Y. Karin M. Science. 1999; 284: 309-313Crossref PubMed Scopus (752) Google Scholar), such a mechanism of NF-κB inhibition by NaSal is inconsistent with the observations that NaSal inhibits TNF-induced but not IL-1-induced IκBα degradation (19.Schwenger P. Alpert D. Skolnik E.Y. Vilcek J. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1998; 18: 78-84Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 26.Madge L.A. Sierra-Honigmann M.R. Pober J.S. J. Biol. Chem. 1999; 274: 13643-13649Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (64) Google Scholar) and that the inhibition by NaSal is p38-dependent (19.Schwenger P. Alpert D. Skolnik E.Y. Vilcek J. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1998; 18: 78-84Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 20.Alpert D. Schwenger P. Han J. Vilcek J. J. Biol. Chem. 1999; 274: 22176-22183Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (100) Google Scholar). To clarify the mechanism by which NaSal inhibits IκBα phosphorylation, we analyzed the effects of NaSal upon cytokine-induced IKK activity in intact cells and in vitro. We conclude that the direct inhibitory effect of NaSal upon IKK activity in vitro does not reflect the mechanism whereby NaSal inhibits IKK activity in intact cells. Studies of IKKα and IKKβ knockout mice indicate that only IKKβ is required for cytokine-induced IκBα degradation, whereas IKKα appears to be important for epidermal differentiation and skeletal morphogenesis (reviewed in Refs. 29.Zandi E. Karin M. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1999; 19: 4547-4551Crossref PubMed Scopus (307) Google Scholar and 30.Karin M. J. Biol. Chem. 1999; 274: 27339-27342Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (620) Google Scholar). Because both TNF- and IL-1-induced IKK activation is impaired in IKKβ−/− cells (31.Li Q. Van Antwerp D. Mercurio F. Lee K.F. Verma I.M. Science. 1999; 284: 321-325Crossref PubMed Scopus (856) Google Scholar, 32.Li Z.W. Chu W. Hu Y. Delhase M. Deerinck T. Ellisman M. Johnson R. Karin M. J. Exp. Med. 1999; 189: 1839-1845Crossref PubMed Scopus (822) Google Scholar, 33.Tanaka M. Fuentes M.E. Yamaguchi K. Durnin M.H. Dalrymple S.A. Hardy K.L. Goeddel D.V. Immunity. 1999; 10: 421-429Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (495) Google Scholar), direct inhibition of IKKβ by NaSal would be expected to impair IKK activation induced by either TNF or IL-1. However, our results demonstrate that treatment of intact cells with NaSal inhibits TNF-induced IKK activity but does not appreciably affect IL-1-induced IKK activity (Fig. 1 A). This observation, in concert with our previous data (19.Schwenger P. Alpert D. Skolnik E.Y. Vilcek J. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1998; 18: 78-84Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 20.Alpert D. Schwenger P. Han J. Vilcek J. J. Biol. Chem. 1999; 274: 22176-22183Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (100) Google Scholar), suggests that NaSal may inhibit NF-κB activation by selectively targeting a component of the TNF signaling pathway leading to IKK activation. On the other hand, treatment of immunoprecipitated IKK with NaSal in vitrodose-dependently inhibited IKK activity from either TNF- or IL-1-treated cells (Fig. 1 B). In addition, we observed that NaSal did not appreciably inhibit either TNF-induced IKK activity or IκBα degradation in intact FS-4 fibroblasts (Fig. 3 A), whereas in vitro treatment of IKK immunoprecipitated from FS-4 cells with 20 mm NaSal led to a strong inhibition of IKK activity (Fig. 3 B). The inhibitory effect of NaSalin vitro is therefore not indicative of its inhibitory profile in whole cells in at least two distinct cell systems. Because the p38 MAP kinase inhibitor SB203580 can prevent the ability of NaSal to inhibit TNF-induced IκBα phosphorylation and degradation (19.Schwenger P. Alpert D. Skolnik E.Y. Vilcek J. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1998; 18: 78-84Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 26.Madge L.A. Sierra-Honigmann M.R. Pober J.S. J. Biol. Chem. 1999; 274: 13643-13649Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (64) Google Scholar), we analyzed the effect of this inhibitor on the ability of NaSal to affect TNF-induced IKK activity. Consistent with previous studies, we observed that incubation of cells with SB203580 significantly prevented the NaSal-mediated inhibition of TNF-induced IKK activity (Fig. 2 A). SB203580 is a specific inhibitor of p38α and p38β isoforms and fails to inhibit the activity of numerous other kinases (34.Cuenda A. Rouse J. Doza Y.N. Meier R. Cohen P. Gallagher T.F. Young P.R. Lee J.C. FEBS Lett. 1995; 364: 229-233Crossref PubMed Scopus (1980) Google Scholar). However, some reports indicate that high concentrations of SB203580 may exert effects unrelated to inhibition of p38 (35.Borsch-Haubold A.G. Pasquet S. Watson S.P. J. Biol. Chem. 1998; 273: 28766-28772Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (254) Google Scholar, 36.Chen C.Y. Del Gatto-Konczak F. Wu Z. Karin M. Science. 1998; 280: 1945-1949Crossref PubMed Scopus (329) Google Scholar, 37.Clerk A. Sugden P.H. FEBS Lett. 1998; 426: 93-96Crossref PubMed Scopus (206) Google Scholar). It seemed possible that SB203580, a low molecular weight imidazole compound, might directly interact with the IKK complex and thereby block NaSal binding. We have ruled out a direct effect of SB203580 on the IKK complex by demonstrating that incubation of immunoprecipitated IKK with SB203580 in vitro, prior to incubation with NaSal, did not reverse the inhibition by NaSal (Fig.2 B). This finding further supports the conclusion that the direct inhibition of IKK activity in vitro does not reflect the mechanism of IKK inhibition by NaSal in vivo. It is likely that the effect of SB203580 in vivo reflects a genuine role for NaSal-induced p38 activation in the inhibition of IKK activity. In support of this notion, diverse stimuli that persistently activate p38, such as hyperosmolarity, H2O2, staurosporine, and vitamin C, similarly inhibited TNF-induced IκBα phosphorylation and degradation in a manner preventable by SB203580 (20.Alpert D. Schwenger P. Han J. Vilcek J. J. Biol. Chem. 1999; 274: 22176-22183Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (100) Google Scholar, 26.Madge L.A. Sierra-Honigmann M.R. Pober J.S. J. Biol. Chem. 1999; 274: 13643-13649Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (64) Google Scholar, 38.Bowie A.G. O'Neill L.A.J. Cytokine. 1999; 11 (abstr.): 934Google Scholar). Furthermore, we demonstrated that a constitutively active MAP kinase kinase 6 mutant, which activates p38, decreased TNF-induced IκBα phosphorylation and NF-κB reporter activity (20.Alpert D. Schwenger P. Han J. Vilcek J. J. Biol. Chem. 1999; 274: 22176-22183Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (100) Google Scholar), and this inhibition occurs at the level of receptor interacting protein or TNF receptor-associated factor 2 in the TNF signaling pathway (data not shown). Other cellular effects of NaSal have been attributed to p38 activation, such as the induction of apoptosis in fibroblasts and induction of adipocyte differentiation (18.Schwenger P. Bellosta P. Vietor I. Basilico C. Skolnik E.Y. Vilcek J. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1997; 94: 2869-2873Crossref PubMed Scopus (256) Google Scholar, 28.Engelman J.A. Berg A.H. Lewis R.Y. Lin A. Lisanti M.P. Scherer P.E. J. Biol. Chem. 1999; 274: 35630-35638Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (99) Google Scholar), suggesting that NaSal may exert multiple biological effects through activation of p38. Although it has been reported that NaSal and aspirin directly inhibit IKKβ but fail to affect IKKα (21.Yin M.J. Yamamoto Y. Gaynor R.B. Nature. 1998; 396: 77-80Crossref PubMed Scopus (1434) Google Scholar), we observed that NaSal inhibited the activity of both immunoprecipitated IKKα and IKKβ in vitro (Fig. 4). We observed significant in vitro andin vivo inhibitory effects of NaSal only at millimolar concentrations, although Yin et al. (21.Yin M.J. Yamamoto Y. Gaynor R.B. Nature. 1998; 396: 77-80Crossref PubMed Scopus (1434) Google Scholar) have demonstrated an IC50 for inhibition of the IKK complex, and IKKβ specifically, at concentrations ranging from 50–100 μm. We cannot explain this discrepancy; however, numerous groups have documented significant effects of NaSal upon NF-κB function, MAP kinase activity, induction of apoptosis, and gene expression only at concentrations of NaSal in the 5–20 mm range (16.Kopp E. Ghosh S. Science. 1994; 265: 956-959Crossref PubMed Scopus (1617) Google Scholar, 17.Pierce J.W. Read M.A. Ding H. Luscinskas F.W. Collins T. J. Immunol. 1996; 156: 3961-3969PubMed Google Scholar, 18.Schwenger P. Bellosta P. Vietor I. Basilico C. Skolnik E.Y. Vilcek J. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1997; 94: 2869-2873Crossref PubMed Scopus (256) Google Scholar,39.Oeth P. Mackman N. Blood. 1995; 86: 4144-4152Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 40.Schwenger P. Skolnik E.Y. Vilcek J. J. Biol. Chem. 1996; 271: 8089-8094Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (83) Google Scholar, 41.Schwenger P. Alpert D. Skolnik E.Y. Vilcek J. J. Cell. Physiol. 1999; 179: 109-114Crossref PubMed Scopus (46) Google Scholar). Although these concentrations exceed the 1–2 mmserum levels that may be achieved in patients undergoing high dose salicylate therapy (15.Abramson S.B. Weissmann G. Arthritis Rheum. 1989; 32: 1-9Crossref PubMed Scopus (418) Google Scholar), they may nonetheless be consistent with a role for p38-mediated NF-κB inhibition in the anti-inflammatory effects of salicylates. As organic acids, salicylates accumulate at the mildly acidic environments prevailing at sites of inflammation (14.Weissmann G. Sci. Am. 1991; 264: 84-90Crossref PubMed Scopus (232) Google Scholar, 15.Abramson S.B. Weissmann G. Arthritis Rheum. 1989; 32: 1-9Crossref PubMed Scopus (418) Google Scholar, 42.Brooks P.M. Day R.O. N. Engl. J. Med. 1991; 324: 1716-1725Crossref PubMed Scopus (814) Google Scholar). Salicylates are uncharged at low pH and can readily cross membranes, yet deprotonate and become trapped as anions in the more neutral environment found within cells (42.Brooks P.M. Day R.O. N. Engl. J. Med. 1991; 324: 1716-1725Crossref PubMed Scopus (814) Google Scholar). Therefore, it is likely that local concentrations of salicylates at sites of inflammation may reach levels sufficient for NF-κB inhibition. Furthermore, studies employing catalytically inactive IKK mutants indicate that slight reductions in IKK activity may correlate with significant decreases in NF-κB-mediated gene expression (8.Mercurio F. Zhu H. Murray B.W. Shevchenko A. Bennett B.L. Li J. Young D.B. Barbosa M. Mann M. Manning A. Rao A. Science. 1997; 278: 860-866Crossref PubMed Scopus (1853) Google Scholar, 9.Zandi E. Rothwarf D.M. Delhase M. Hayakawa M. Karin M. Cell. 1997; 91: 243-252Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (1589) Google Scholar), suggesting that the reduction in TNF-induced IKK activity observed at 1–5 mm NaSal (Fig.1 A) is likely to translate into biologically relevant NF-κB inhibition. Interestingly, we noted that millimolar concentrations of NaSal significantly inhibited p38 MAP kinase activity in vitro(Fig. 5). However, treatment of numerous cell types with millimolar concentrations of NaSal leads to p38 activation rather than to its inhibition (18.Schwenger P. Bellosta P. Vietor I. Basilico C. Skolnik E.Y. Vilcek J. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1997; 94: 2869-2873Crossref PubMed Scopus (256) Google Scholar, 19.Schwenger P. Alpert D. Skolnik E.Y. Vilcek J. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1998; 18: 78-84Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 28.Engelman J.A. Berg A.H. Lewis R.Y. Lin A. Lisanti M.P. Scherer P.E. J. Biol. Chem. 1999; 274: 35630-35638Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (99) Google Scholar). This finding further underscores the notion that the effect of NaSal upon in vitro kinase activity does not reflect the mechanism by which NaSal affects various kinases within the cell. Furthermore, the inhibitory action on p38 in vitroindicates that the effect of NaSal upon in vitro kinase activity is not limited to the IKKs. In agreement with this conclusion, it was recently reported that 20 mm NaSal inhibits RSK2 kinase activity in vitro (43.Stevenson M.A. Zhao M.J. Asea A. Coleman C.N. Calderwood S.K. J. Immunol. 1999; 163: 5608-5616PubMed Google Scholar). Overall, our results emphasize the need to exercise caution when attributing the actions of pharmacological agents in intact cells to effects observed in vitro without thoroughly considering potential interactions with various signal transduction components. We also thank Matthew Mulvey and Anthony Quagliata for technical assistance, Ilene Totillo for assistance with preparation of the manuscript, and Dr. Paul Schwenger for critical reading of the manuscript.

LmrA, a membrane protein of Lactococcus lactis, extrudes amphiphilic compounds from the inner leaflet of the cytoplasmic membrane, using energy derived from ATP hydrolysis. A combination of total reflection Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy, 2H/H exchange, and fluorescence quenching experiments was used to investigate the effect of nucleotide binding and/or hydrolysis on the structure of LmrA reconstituted into proteoliposomes. These measurements allowed us to describe secondary structure changes of LmrA during the catalytic cycle. The structure of LmrA is enriched in β-sheet after ATP binding, and the protein recovers its initial secondary structure after ATP hydrolysis, when Pi has been released. 2H/H exchange and fluorescence quenching studies indicate that the protein undergoes two distinct tertiary structure changes during the hydrolysis process. Indeed, the protein alone is poorly accessible to the aqueous medium but adopts a more accessible conformation when ATP hydrolysis takes place. After ATP hydrolysis, but when Pi is still associated with the protein, the accessibility is intermediate between these two states. A combination of total reflection Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy, 2H/H exchange, and fluorescence quenching experiments was used to investigate the effect of nucleotide binding and/or hydrolysis on the structure of LmrA reconstituted into proteoliposomes. These measurements allowed us to describe secondary structure changes of LmrA during the catalytic cycle. The structure of LmrA is enriched in β-sheet after ATP binding, and the protein recovers its initial secondary structure after ATP hydrolysis, when Pi has been released. 2H/H exchange and fluorescence quenching studies indicate that the protein undergoes two distinct tertiary structure changes during the hydrolysis process. Indeed, the protein alone is poorly accessible to the aqueous medium but adopts a more accessible conformation when ATP hydrolysis takes place. After ATP hydrolysis, but when Pi is still associated with the protein, the accessibility is intermediate between these two states. P-glycoprotein ATP-binding cassette adenosine-5′-O-(thiotriphosphate) attenuated total reflection Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy Multidrug resistance causes serious problems in the treatment of cancer and infectious diseases (1.Nikaido H. Science. 1994; 264: 382-388Crossref PubMed Scopus (1261) Google Scholar, 2.Gottesman M.M. Cancer Res. 1993; 53: 747-754PubMed Google Scholar). Overexpression of P-glycoprotein (Pgp),1 a 170-kDa plasma membrane protein, is implicated in multidrug resistance of different cancer cell lines (3.Pastan I. Gottesman M.M. Annu. Rev. Med. 1991; 42: 277-286Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 4.Endicott J.A. Ling V. Annu. Rev. Biochem. 1989; 58: 137-171Crossref PubMed Scopus (2018) Google Scholar, 5.Chan H.S. Haddad G. Thorner P.S. DeBoer G. Lin Y.P. Ondrusek N. Yeger H. Ling V. N. Engl. J. Med. 1991; 325: 1608-1614Crossref PubMed Scopus (437) Google Scholar). Pgp belongs to the ATP-binding cassette (ABC) superfamily and functions as an ATP-driven efflux pump that transports a broad spectrum of structurally unrelated cytotoxic drugs (6.Gottesman M.M. Pastan I. Annu. Rev. Biochem. 1993; 62: 385-427Crossref PubMed Scopus (3564) Google Scholar, 7.Chin K. Pastan I. Gottesman M. Adv. Cancer Res. 1993; 60: 157-180Crossref PubMed Scopus (175) Google Scholar, 8.Sharom F.J., Yu, X. Doige C.A. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 24197-24202Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Several multidrug transport proteins have been identified in bacteria (1.Nikaido H. Science. 1994; 264: 382-388Crossref PubMed Scopus (1261) Google Scholar). Most of them are secondary transporters, acting as drug/H+ antiporter (9.van Veen H.W. Konings W.N. Biol. Chem. 1997; 378: 769-777PubMed Google Scholar). LmrA from Lactococcus lactis was the first ABC multidrug transporter identified in bacteria (10.van Veen H.W. Venema K. Bolhuis H. Oussenko I. Kok J. Poolman B. Driessen A.J. Konings W.N. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1996; 93: 10668-10672Crossref PubMed Scopus (256) Google Scholar, 11.Bolhuis H. Molenaar D. Poelarends G. van Veen H.W. Poolman B. Driessen A.J. Konings W.N. J. Bacteriol. 1994; 176: 6957-6964Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). It is a 590-amino acid protein containing an N-terminal membrane domain, consisting of six transmembrane segments, followed by a hydrophilic domain containing the nucleotide binding site. This transporter uses the free energy of ATP hydrolysis to transport a broad range of amphiphilic drugs across the membrane. Although its topology in the lipid membrane has been deduced from its primary structure, its secondary and tertiary structures are unknown. Interestingly, LmrA and each half of Pgp share a high level of sequence homology, including regions implicated in drug recognition and transport in Pgp (10.van Veen H.W. Venema K. Bolhuis H. Oussenko I. Kok J. Poolman B. Driessen A.J. Konings W.N. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1996; 93: 10668-10672Crossref PubMed Scopus (256) Google Scholar). LmrA and Pgp extrude a similar spectrum of amphiphilic cationic compounds, and their activities are reversed by reserpine and verapamil. Furthermore, LmrA can even functionally complement Pgp in human fibroblast cells (12.van Veen H.W. Callaghan R. Soceneantu L. Sardini A. Konings W.N. Higgins C.F. Nature. 1998; 391: 291-295Crossref PubMed Scopus (217) Google Scholar). Previous studies, including infrared spectroscopy (13.Sonveaux N. Shapiro A.B. Goormaghtigh E. Ling V. Ruysschaert J.-M. J. Biol. Chem. 1996; 271: 24617-24624Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (105) Google Scholar), tryptophan quenching (14.Sonveaux N. Vigano C. Shapiro A.B. Ling V. Ruysschaert J.-M. J. Biol. Chem. 1999; 274: 17649-17654Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (85) Google Scholar), enzymatic proteolysis (15.Wang G. Pincheira R. Zhang J.T. Eur. J. Biochem. 1998; 255: 383-390Crossref PubMed Scopus (57) Google Scholar, 16.Wang G. Pincheira R. Zhang M. Zhang J.T. Biochem. J. 1997; 328: 897-904Crossref PubMed Scopus (57) Google Scholar), and immunoreactivity measurements (17.Mechetner E.B. Schott B. Morse B.S. Stein W.D. Druley T. Davis K.A. Tsuruo T. Roninson I.B. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1997; 94: 12908-12913Crossref PubMed Scopus (174) Google Scholar), have demonstrated that Pgp changes its conformation during its catalytic cycle, and four conformational states have been identified during the hydrolysis cycle. The mechanism of coupling ATP hydrolysis, at the cytoplasmic nucleotide binding domain, to drug transport probably involves conformational changes in LmrA structure. Knowledge of these intermediate states is essential for understanding the LmrA-induced transport process. The main goal of the present study is to investigate the different conformations adopted by the protein in the presence of nucleotide ligands. Recently, histidine-tagged LmrA was overexpressed in L. lactis and purified using a Ni2+-NTA affinity chromatography. LmrA was reconstituted into liposomes prepared fromL. lactis lipids (18.Margolles A. Putman M. van Veen H.W. Konings W.N. Biochemistry. 1999; 38: 16298-16306Crossref PubMed Scopus (128) Google Scholar) and from Escherichia colilipids. 2A. Margolles, H. W. van Veen, and W. N. Konings, unpublished data. The resulting proteoliposomes exhibited ATP-dependent drug transport, which was inhibited by chemosensitizers (18.Margolles A. Putman M. van Veen H.W. Konings W.N. Biochemistry. 1999; 38: 16298-16306Crossref PubMed Scopus (128) Google Scholar). We investigated here the effect of MgATPγS, MgATP, MgADP/Pi, and MgADP on the secondary and tertiary structures of LmrA, using a combination of FTIR spectroscopy, 2H/H exchange, and fluorescence quenching measurements. MgATPγS, the nonhydrolyzable analog of MgATP, was used to discriminate between the influence of nucleotide binding and nucleotide hydrolysis on LmrA structure. The structure of LmrA in the presence of MgADP/Pi and MgADP represents the situation after hydrolysis. This study clearly indicates that the secondary and tertiary structures of LmrA change during its catalytic cycle and allowed us to describe intermediate states involved in the hydrolysis process. ATP, ATPγS, and ADP were from Sigma. D2O was from Merck, Ni2+-nitrilotriacetic acid resin was from Qiagen, Bio-Beads SM2 were from Bio-Rad, polycarbonate filters were from Avestin, and dodecyl-β-d-maltoside was from Anatrace.E. coli lipids and l-α-phosphatidylcholine from egg yolk were purchased from Avanti Polar Lipids. The purification of LmrA was carried out essentially as described previously (18.Margolles A. Putman M. van Veen H.W. Konings W.N. Biochemistry. 1999; 38: 16298-16306Crossref PubMed Scopus (128) Google Scholar). Inside-out membrane vesicles, containing overexpressed LmrA, were solubilized in 50 mm potassium phosphate, pH 8, containing 10% (v/v) glycerol, 100 mmNaCl, and 1% (w/v) dodecyl-β-d-maltoside. After 30 min of incubation at 4 °C, the insoluble material was removed by centrifugation. The supernatant was mixed and incubated for 1 h at 4 °C with Ni2+-nitrilotriacetic acid-agarose (∼8 mg of LmrA/ml of resin), which was preequilibrated in buffer A (50 mm potassium phosphate, pH 8, 100 mm NaCl, 10% glycerol, and 0.05% dodecyl-β-d-maltoside) plus 10 mm imidazole. The resin was transferred to a Bio-spin column (Bio-Rad) and washed with 20 column volumes of buffer A containing 10 mm of imidazole and subsequently with 40 column volumes of buffer A (pH 7) plus 40 mm of imidazole. The protein was eluted with buffer A, pH 7, supplemented with 150 mm of imidazole. Liposomes of acetone/ether-washed E. coli lipids andl-α-phosphatidylcholine from egg yolk, in a ratio (w/w) of 3:1, were made by dissolving lipids in 50 mm potassium phosphate, pH 7, at a final concentration of 20 mg/ml. Unilamellar liposomes with relatively homogeneous size were prepared by freezing in liquid nitrogen and slow thawing at room temperature followed by extrusion of the liposomes 12 times through a 400-nm polycarbonate filter. The reconstitution of LmrA into liposomes was carried out essentially as described (18.Margolles A. Putman M. van Veen H.W. Konings W.N. Biochemistry. 1999; 38: 16298-16306Crossref PubMed Scopus (128) Google Scholar), using a protein/lipid ratio of 1:10. The resulting proteoliposomes exhibited ATP-dependent drug transport, inhibited by chemosensitizers (18.Margolles A. Putman M. van Veen H.W. Konings W.N. Biochemistry. 1999; 38: 16298-16306Crossref PubMed Scopus (128) Google Scholar). Proteoliposomes were resuspended at a final protein concentration of 1 mg/ml in 3 mm potassium Hepes, pH 7.4. ATR-FTIR spectra were recorded, at room temperature, on a Bruker IFS55 FTIR spectrophotometer equipped with a liquid nitrogen-cooled mercury-cadmium-telluride detector at a nominal resolution of 4 cm−1 and encoded every 1 cm−1. The spectrophotometer was continuously purged with air. The internal reflection element (ATR) was a germanium plate (50 × 20 × 2 mm; Harrick EJ2121) with an aperture angle of 45°, yielding 25 internal reflections (19.Goormaghtigh E. Cabiaux V. Ruysschaert J.M. Eur. J. Biochem. 1990; 193: 409-420Crossref PubMed Scopus (465) Google Scholar). For each spectrum, used for the determination of the secondary structure, 512 scan cycles were averaged. For each kinetic time point, 24 spectra were recorded and averaged. In each cycle, the sample spectra were rationed against the background spectrum of a clean germanium plate. Thin films of oriented multilayers were obtained by slowly evaporating the sample on one side of the ATR plate in a stream of nitrogen (20.Fringeli U. Günthard H. Grell E. Membrane Spectroscopy. Springer, Berlin1981: 270-332Google Scholar). The ATR plate was then sealed in a universal sample holder. The sample contained 20 μg of reconstituted LmrA. For measurements of LmrA structure in the presence of different nucleotides, 0.5 μl of a 6 mm nucleotide or Pi solution was added to the reconstituted protein. In these conditions, the molar ratio of LmrA over nucleotides is 1:5. The sample on the ATR plate was rehydrated by flushing D2O-saturated N2 for 2 h at room temperature. 512 scans were averaged for each measurement. The determination of the secondary structure was based on the vibrational bands of the protein and particularly the amide I band (1600–1700 cm−1), which is sensitive to the secondary structure (20.Fringeli U. Günthard H. Grell E. Membrane Spectroscopy. Springer, Berlin1981: 270-332Google Scholar). This amide I band, located in a region of the spectrum that is often free of other bands, is composed of 80% pure C=O vibration. The analysis was performed on the amide I region of deuterated samples, because the H/D exchange allows differentiation of the α-helical secondary structure from the random secondary structure whose absorption band shifts from about 1655 to about 1642 cm−1 (21.Goormaghtigh E. Cabiaux V. Ruysschaert J.M. Subcell. Biochem. 1994; 23: 329-450Crossref PubMed Scopus (306) Google Scholar). Fourier self-deconvolution was applied to increase the resolution of the spectra in the amide I region. The self-deconvolution was carried out using a Lorentzian line shape for the deconvolution and a Gaussian line shape for the apodization. To quantify the area of the different components of amide I revealed by self-deconvolution, a least squares iterative curve fitting was performed to fit Lorentzian line shapes to the spectrum between 1700 and 1600 cm−1 (21.Goormaghtigh E. Cabiaux V. Ruysschaert J.M. Subcell. Biochem. 1994; 23: 329-450Crossref PubMed Scopus (306) Google Scholar, 22.Kauppinen J.K. Moffat D.J. Cameron D.G. Mantsch H. Appl. Opt. 1981; 20: 1866-1879Crossref PubMed Scopus (213) Google Scholar, 23.Susi H. Byler D.M. Biopolymers. 1986; 25: 459-487Google Scholar). To avoid the introduction of artifacts due to the self-deconvolution procedure, the fitting was performed on the nondeconvoluted spectrum. The proportion of a particular structure is the sum of the area of all of the fitted Lorentzian bands having their maximum in the frequency region where that structure occurs divided by the total area of the amide I. The frequency limits for each structure were first assigned according to theoretical (24.Krimm S. Bandekar J. Adv. Protein Chem. 1986; 38: 181-364Crossref PubMed Scopus (2700) Google Scholar) or experimental (23.Susi H. Byler D.M. Biopolymers. 1986; 25: 459-487Google Scholar) data: 1662–1645 cm−1, α-helix; 1689–1682 and 1637–1613 cm−1, β-sheet; 1644.5–1637 cm−1, random; 1682–1662.5 cm−1, β-turns. These limits have been slightly adjusted to obtain a good agreement between the proportion of each structure determined by ATR-FTIR and x-ray crystallography (19.Goormaghtigh E. Cabiaux V. Ruysschaert J.M. Eur. J. Biochem. 1990; 193: 409-420Crossref PubMed Scopus (465) Google Scholar). Films containing 20 μg of reconstituted LmrA, in the presence or absence of nucleotides, were prepared on a germanium plate as described above. Nitrogen was saturated with D2O by bubbling in a series of three vials containing D2O. Before starting the deuteration, 10 spectra of the sample were recorded to test the stability of the measurements and the reproducibility of the area determination. At zero time, the D2O-saturated N2 flux, at a flow rate of 100 ml/min (controlled by a Brooks flow meter), was connected to the sample. For each kinetic time point, 24 spectra were recorded and averaged at a resolution of 4 cm−1. The signal from the atmospheric water was subtracted as described by Goormaghtigh et al. (25.Goormaghtigh E. Ruysschaert J.M. Spectrochim. Acta. 1994; 50: 2137-3144Crossref Scopus (73) Google Scholar). The area of amide II, characteristic of the δ(N-H) vibration, was obtained by integration between 1596 and 1502 cm−1. For each spectrum, the area of amide II was divided by the corresponding lipidic ν(C=O) area to correct for any change in total intensity of the spectra during the deuteration process (26.Goormaghtigh E. Raussens V. Ruysschaert J.M. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1999; 1422: 105-185Crossref PubMed Scopus (513) Google Scholar). This ratio, expressed as a percentage was plotted versusdeuteration time. The 100% value is defined by the amide II/lipid ratio obtained before deuteration. The 0% value corresponds to a zero absorption in the amide II region, observed for a full deuteration of the protein. Acrylamide quenching experiments were carried out on an SLM Aminco 8000 fluorimeter at an excitation wavelength of 290 nm to reduce the absorbance of acrylamide. Acrylamide aliquots were added from a 3m solution to the proteoliposome suspension containing 6.5 μg of reconstituted LmrA and the various ligands. The final concentrations for MgATP, MgADP, MgATPγS, and Pi were 3 mm. Fluorescence intensities were measured at 332 nm after each addition of quencher. All measurements were carried out at 25 °C. Acrylamide quenching data were analyzed according to the Stern-Volmer equation for collisional quenching (27.Lehrer S.S. Biochemistry. 1971; 10: 3254-3263Crossref PubMed Scopus (1678) Google Scholar), F0/F=1+K[Q]Equation 1 where F 0 and F represent the fluorescence intensities in the absence and presence of quencher, [Q] is the molar concentration of quencher, and K is the Stern-Volmer quenching constant. Data were subjected to a linear fit up to 80 mm acrylamide. Above this concentration, the static quenching by acrylamide causes a deviation from linearity in Stern-Volmer plots. Spectra of LmrA reconstituted into lipids were recorded in the absence and presence of different nucleotides (MgATP, MgATPγS, MgADP, MgADP/Pi). The IR spectrum of LmrA alone, in the 1800–1400-cm−1 region, is shown in Fig. 1. The amide I band, assigned to the ν(C=O) of the peptide bond, is located in the 1700–1600-cm−1 region. The 1570–1500- and the 1500-1400-cm−1 bands represent unexchanged amide II, characteristic of the δ(N-H), and exchanged amide II, characteristic of the δ(N-D) amide bond, respectively. The lipid ester ν(C=O) band is located in the 1700–1800-cm−1 region. The secondary structure of LmrA was determined by Fourier deconvolution and a curve-fitting analysis of the amide I region of a deuterated sample. The percentages of α-helix, β-sheet, β-turn, and random coil structures, in the presence or absence of nucleotides, are presented in Table I. Significant differences detected in the amide I region of LmrA demonstrate that LmrA adopts two different conformations depending on the nature of the nucleotide bound to the protein (Fig. 2). LmrA alone or in the presence of ADP has 35% α-helix, 24% β-sheet, 28% β-turn, and 13% random coil. In the presence of MgATP, MgATPγS, or MgADP/Pi, an enrichment in β-sheet is observed (35% α-helix, 34% β-sheet, 17% β-turn, and 14% random coil) concomitantly with a loss of β-turn structure. Kinetics of deuteration of reconstituted LmrA were monitored in the presence and absence of different nucleotides (MgATP, MgATPγS, MgADP, MgADP/Pi). The rate of amide hydrogen exchange by deuterium is related to the solvent accessibility to the NH amide groups. Amide hydrogen exchange was followed by monitoring the amide II absorption peak (maximum at 1544 cm−1) as a function of the time of exposure to D2O-saturated N2. The percentage of exchange was computed between 0 and 100%, as explained under “Experimental Procedures.” The decrease of the amide II region is proportional to the number of hydrogens that have been exchanged by deuterium and provides a sensitive measure of LmrA structure and conformational changes. Deuterium-hydrogen exchange is shown in Fig.3 as a function of the deuteration time. Deuterium-hydrogen exchange is extremely rapid in all of the situations tested; a drastic decrease in the intensity of the amide II band is observed during the first 10 min of exposure, indicating a rapid exchange of a large number of amide hydrogen for deuterium. Deuterium-hydrogen exchange is much slower over the next 2 h. In the absence of nucleotide, about 55% of amide hydrogens of LmrA are not exchanged for deuterium, reflecting a poor accessibility of these hydrogens to the aqueous medium. This percentage is not significantly affected by ADP or ATPγS binding. The addition of ATP to LmrA, however, clearly results in an increase of the deuterium-hydrogen exchange rate. About 43% of amide hydrogens do not exchange. In the presence of MgADP/Pi, the exchange rate is between the rates observed for LmrA alone and in the presence of ATP; 49% of the hydrogen bonds do not exchange. Hydrogen atoms with different exchange rates are implicated in the exchange process. Since the 2H/H exchange is a first order reaction, the exchange curve is expected to display a multiexponential decay corresponding to the different groups of amide protons characterized by a common period T i, H(t)=∑iai exp(−t/Ti)Equation 2 where a i is the proportion of each amide group with identical T i values. The large number of protons makes it impossible to obtain the individual rate constants. Information about the variation in rate constants can be obtained by arbitrarily selection of a number of exponentials to fit the exchange curves. Three exponentials characterized by their period T i (i= 1–3) and by their proportion a i of amide groups were chosen. In order to compare the proportion a iof each amide group for the different experimental curves, the sameT i values are used for all of the fittings. To characterize the amount of very fast (a 1), intermediate (a 2), and very slowly (a 3) exchanging protons, periods of 10 s, 2 min, and 500 min, respectively were chosen. In the absence of ligands, approximately 30% of the amide hydrogen exchanged for deuterium within 10 s of exposure to 2H2O, and an additional 15% exchanged after 2 min (TableII). The remaining 54% exchanged after 8 h, and these protons represent the very inaccessible regions of LmrA. In the presence of ATP and ADP/Pi, the fraction of slowly exchanging amide protons (characterized bya 3, T 3), decrease concomitant with an increase of intermediate exchanging amide protons (characterized by a 2,T 2). In the presence of MgATPγS and MgADP, the fraction of slowly exchanging amide protons is almost identical to that observed for LmrA alone. The accessibility of LmrA to the aqueous medium was measured in the presence or absence of nucleotides. MgATP, MgADP, MgATPγS, and Pi were added to a final concentration of 3 mm. The exposure of the tryptophan residues of LmrA to the external solvent was determined by monitoring the LmrA fluorescence intensity in the presence of increasing concentrations (0–0.08 m) of the aqueous quencher acrylamide (28.Eftink M.R. Ghiron C.A. Biochemistry. 1976; 15: 672-679Crossref PubMed Scopus (989) Google Scholar, 29.Eftink M.R. Ghiron C.A. Anal. Biochem. 1981; 114: 199-227Crossref PubMed Scopus (1625) Google Scholar). Stern-Volmer plots of fluorescence quenching of the tryptophan of LmrA by acrylamide, in the presence or absence of MgATP, MgADP, MgATPγS, and MgADP/Pi, are shown in Fig.4. The lowest accessibility was observed for LmrA alone or in the presence of MgATPγS or MgADP. In the presence of MgATP, the Trp accessibility to the aqueous environment is strongly enhanced. An intermediate level was observed for LmrA in the presence of MgADP/Pi. These observations indicate clearly that binding of MgATP itself does not affect the accessibility of tryptophan to the aqueous medium but that ATP hydrolysis is needed to increase the Trp accessibility to the aqueous quencher. After hydrolysis, when Pi is still associated with LmrA, Trp accessibility decreases to a intermediate level. After Pirelease, the initial accessibility of Trp to the solvent is restored. A. 1997; 94: 12908-12913Crossref PubMed Scopus (174) Google Scholar). The present study provides evidence that its procaryotic homolog LmrA undergoes similar secondary and tertiary structural changes during the ATP hydrolysis process. Purified and functionally reconstituted LmrA into liposomes (18.Margolles A. Putman M. van Veen H.W. Konings W.N. Biochemistry. 1999; 38: 16298-16306Crossref PubMed Scopus (128) Google Scholar) does not contain other cellular constituents and is therefore ideally suited for analysis of the protein structure by ATR-FTIR and fluorescence quenching experiments. ATR-FTIR measurements reveal that LmrA, in the absence of nucleotides, contains 35% α-helix, 24% β-sheet, 28% β-turn, and 13% random coil. This proportion of α-helices is higher than the proportion expected when only six transmembrane segments (20%) are in an α-helical conformation. External α-helices therefore have to be present. Interestingly, the proportions of the different secondary structures in LmrA is similar to that determined for Pgp by ATR-FTIR (13.Sonveaux N. Shapiro A.B. Goormaghtigh E. Ling V. Ruysschaert J.-M. J. Biol. Chem. 1996; 271: 24617-24624Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (105) Google Scholar). The addition of MgATP, MgADP/Pi, and MgATPγS leads to a reorganization of the hydrogen bonds of the protein as indicated by the enrichment of β-sheet conformation (approximately 10%) in LmrA. LmrA clearly stabilizes in a different secondary structure after ATP binding. It falls back to its initial secondary structure after Pi release, when ADP is still bound to LmrA. Three hypotheses could explain this ATP binding-mediated change of the secondary structure. ATP binding could cause a reorganization of the drug binding site(s). In Pgp, the membrane-spanning α-helices are implicated in drug recognition and transport (30.Chen C.-J. Chin J.E. Ueda K. Clark D.P. Pastan I. Gottesman M.M. Roninson I.B. Cell. 1986; 47: 381-387Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (1717) Google Scholar, 31.Loo T.W. Clarke D.M. J. Biol. Chem. 1999; 274: 24759-24765Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (134) Google Scholar, 32.Greenberger L.M. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 11417-11425Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). In analogy, the sequence homologies between LmrA and each half of Pgp (10.van Veen H.W. Venema K. Bolhuis H. Oussenko I. Kok J. Poolman B. Driessen A.J. Konings W.N. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1996; 93: 10668-10672Crossref PubMed Scopus (256) Google Scholar) strongly suggest that the same holds for LmrA. Since the α-helix content of LmrA is similar to that of Pgp and does not change in the presence of nucleotides, this first hypothesis probably does not explain the secondary structure change of LmrA. ATP binding could also mediate a reorganization of its binding site. Since the ATPase activities of LmrA and Pgp are very similar (12.van Veen H.W. Callaghan R. Soceneantu L. Sardini A. Konings W.N. Higgins C.F. Nature. 1998; 391: 291-295Crossref PubMed Scopus (217) Google Scholar) and since Pgp does not show an enrichment in β-sheet that could change its ability to bind or hydrolyze ATP (13.Sonveaux N. Shapiro A.B. Goormaghtigh E. Ling V. Ruysschaert J.-M. J. Biol. Chem. 1996; 271: 24617-24624Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (105) Google Scholar), this explanation must be rejected. Since this enrichment in β-sheet is not observed for Pgp and since the ATPase and transport activities of Pgp and LmrA are very similar, it can be postulated that the secondary structure change observed for LmrA after ATP binding is related to a typical behavior of this protein. The primary structure homology of LmrA and each half of Pgp demonstrates that LmrA is a half-molecule of Pgp (10.van Veen H.W. Venema K. Bolhuis H. Oussenko I. Kok J. Poolman B. Driessen A.J. Konings W.N. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1996; 93: 10668-10672Crossref PubMed Scopus (256) Google Scholar). Their comparable activities suggest that LmrA must be homodimeric to be active. This has been confirmed recently by fusion of two functional LmrA molecules. 3H. W. van Veen, A. Margolles, M. Müller, R. Callaghan, C. Martin, C. F. Higgins, and W. N. Konings, submitted for publication. Consequently, ATP could mediate the secondary structural change required for the organization of LmrA in its homodimeric form. After ATP hydrolysis and Pi release, the protein recovers its initial secondary structure and monomeric form. Amide 2H/H exchange, followed during the time of exposure of the sample to D2O-saturated N2, allows us to determine the accessibility of the amide hydrogens to the aqueous medium. The kinetics of deuteration of LmrA were observed in the presence or absence of MgATP, MgATPγS, MgADP, and MgADP/Pi. 2H/H exchange measurements provided evidence that a large portion of LmrA is poorly accessible to the aqueous medium. The slowly exchanging amino acids, characterized by a half-decay T 3 = 500 min, represent 55% of the total amino acid content of the protein. The presence of a large amide population, characterized by a very low exchange rate, could be due, in part, to the shielding effect of the membrane on a large number of residues. Transmembrane domains of several membrane proteins, as glycophorin and bacteriorhodopsin, are inaccessible to the solvent as shown by their slow kinetics of amide 2H/H exchange (33.Challou N. Goormaghtigh E. Cabiaux V. Conrath K. Ruysschaert J.M. Biochemistry. 1994; 33: 6902-6910Crossref PubMed Scopus (43) Google Scholar,34.Vigneron L. Ruysschaert J.M. Goormaghtigh E. J. Biol. Chem. 1995; 270: 17685-17696Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (34) Google Scholar). The slowly exchanging amide protons of LmrA could therefore be formed by a core of amino acids located within the membrane. However, according to the protein sequence, the predicted transmembrane domains of LmrA account for only 20% of the total amino acids (10.van Veen H.W. Venema K. Bolhuis H. Oussenko I. Kok J. Poolman B. Driessen A.J. Konings W.N. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1996; 93: 10668-10672Crossref PubMed Scopus (256) Google Scholar). A significant proportion of the slowly exchanging amino acids must therefore form additional membrane domains or be located outside the membrane, where they probably form highly structured domains. The kinetics of deuteration of Pgp showed also a large inaccessible fraction (53%) of the protein, whereas only 20% of the total amino acid content of the protein is predicted to be located inside the membrane, suggesting the existence of similar highly structured domains outside the membrane (13.Sonveaux N. Shapiro A.B. Goormaghtigh E. Ling V. Ruysschaert J.-M. J. Biol. Chem. 1996; 271: 24617-24624Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (105) Google Scholar). The analysis of the amide 2H/H exchange rates allows a determination of the effects of the secondary structure change, observed in the presence of MgATP, MgATPγS, and MgADP/Pi, on the accessibility of LmrA to the aqueous medium. The main changes in the accessibility of LmrA take place in the presence of MgATP. In the presence of MgATP, the inaccessible amino acids decrease from 318 to 260. In the presence of MgADP/Pi, the inaccessible amino acids only decrease to 289, while no changes are observed with MgADP or MgATPγS. Obviously, the secondary structural change, observed in the presence of MgATP, MgATPγS, and MgADP/Pi, is not responsible for the accessibility change of LmrA. Indeed, LmrA in the presence of MgATPγS shows an enrichment in β-sheet but no variation in the inaccessible amino acids, when compared with the situation in the absence of ligand. Since the change of accessibility, observed in the presence of MgATP and MgADP/Pi, is not related to the change of secondary structure, it could be correlated to a change in the tertiary structure of LmrA. A similar effect of MgATP on the accessibility of Pgp has been demonstrated (13.Sonveaux N. Shapiro A.B. Goormaghtigh E. Ling V. Ruysschaert J.-M. J. Biol. Chem. 1996; 271: 24617-24624Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (105) Google Scholar, 14.Sonveaux N. Vigano C. Shapiro A.B. Ling V. Ruysschaert J.-M. J. Biol. Chem. 1999; 274: 17649-17654Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (85) Google Scholar). Fluorescence quenching experiments confirm the existence of conformational changes of LmrA in the presence of MgATP or MgADP/Pi. The quenching of the Trp fluorescence of LmrA is the same in the presence or absence of MgATPγS, confirming that the change in the secondary structure does not affect the accessibility of the protein to the aqueous medium. MgADP does not modify the accessibility of the protein, as observed for the 2H/H kinetics. The results of this study reveal that LmrA undergoes a secondary structure change and passes through three different conformational states during its catalytic cycle. After binding of ATP, the protein structure is enriched in β-sheet. When ATP hydrolysis takes place, the tertiary structure of the protein changes, and the protein adopts a more accessible conformation. A third conformation is reached after ATP hydrolysis, when Pi is still associated to the protein. In this conformation, the protein shows an accessibility that is in between the closed conformation, observed in the absence of nucleotides, and the opened conformation, observed in the presence of ATP. After Pi release, the protein recovers its initial secondary and tertiary structures.

Basic fibroblast growth factor (FGF2) is a potent mitogen for medial smooth muscle cells and is necessary for their proliferation after balloon catheter injury; however, intimal smooth muscle cells do not require FGF2 for their proliferation, and they respond only weakly to exogenous FGF2. The present study examined the activation of extracellular signal-regulated kinase (ERK) signaling as well as the expression and activity of cell cycle proteins in FGF2-stimulated intimal smooth muscle cells. FGF2 activates ERKs 1 and 2, and Western blot analysis showed that cyclin D, cyclin E, and cyclin-dependent kinase (CDKs) 2 and 4 were expressed in intimal smooth muscle cells after FGF2 infusion. FGF2 stimulation, however, did not lead to phosphorylation of the retinoblastoma protein (Rb), CDK 2 activation, or expression of cyclin A. Western blot analysis showed that intimal smooth muscle cells express elevated levels of the cell cycle inhibitors p15<sup>INK4b</sup> and p27<sup>Kip1</sup>, compared with medial smooth muscle cells, and that FGF2 stimulation does not reduce the level of these inhibitors. These studies suggest that despite activation of ERKs 1 and 2 and expression of the cell cycle activators, cyclin D and cyclin E, high levels of cell cycle inhibitors may inhibit cell cycle transit in FGF2-stimulated intimal smooth muscle cells.

Parathyroid hormone (PTH-(1–34)) potently suppresses apatite deposition in osteoblastic cultures. These inhibitory effects are mediated through signaling events following PTH receptor binding. Using both selective inhibitors and activators of protein kinase A (PKA), this study shows that a transient activation of PKA is sufficient to account for PTH's inhibition of apatite deposition. This inhibition is not a result of reduced cell proliferation, reduced alkaline phosphatase activity, increased collagenase production, or lowering medium pH. Rather, data suggest a functional relationship between matrix assembly and apatite depositionin vitro. Bone sialoprotein (BSP) and apatite co-localize in the extracellular matrix of mineralizing cultures, with matrix deposition of BSP temporally preceding that of apatite. Transient activation of PKA by either PTH-(1–34) or short term cAMP analog treatment blocks the deposition of BSP in the extracellular matrix without a significant reduction in the total amount of BSP synthesized and secreted. This effect is reversible after allowing the cultures to recover in the absence of PKA activators for several days. Thus, a transient activation of PKA may suppress mineral deposition in vitro as a consequence of altering the assembly of an extracellular matrix permissive for apatite formation.
